title: Firefox built-in PDF viewer stuck in light mode when privacy.resistFingerprinting is enabled
content:
Hi everyone,

After enabling `privacy.resistFingerprinting = true` in `about:config`, I noticed that Firefox’s built-in PDF viewer (`pdf.js`) is always displayed in **light mode**, even though my system and browser themes are both dark.

I understand that RFP forces `prefers-color-scheme: light` to prevent fingerprinting, but this also affects internal components like the PDF reader. Unfortunately, the PDF viewer doesn’t provide a manual dark mode toggle.

Is there any **official or safe workaround** that allows keeping RFP enabled while still having the PDF viewer use dark colors?

Thanks!
creator: Ariel

title: Blasted Federal Government keeps changing the rules  Cannot get in they blame M/FF
content:
The Government has to keep changing. "for our Security". We have accounts with the Veterans Affairs medical stuff for our medical stuff. NOW we had to move to Login.Gov or another website. It was horrible, but I FINALLY got the Olde Marine & Myself 2 Different accounts (i.e. 2 different email addresses) in Login.gov. VA has continued making changes & since Friday I can not get into "My Healthy Vet 

i.e. I go through the steps & when I type in the e-dress & password MY PHONE SHOULD RING with a numeric code.  Once I type in the Numeric Code, I can continue to scramble around trying to access our pharmacy or our 'care team' in the VA system.

I watch the screen, nothing happens. I wait for the phone call nothing happens. I look in my email box & there is a message from Login.Gov that a code was sent to me. NOPE.

I have no idea why. as a cat like nosy person, I am always needing to know why. What is wrong? Is it the government & if so forget it as they most likely won't answer the phone. Is it Charter Spectrum? Is it Mozilla Firefox? (whine) I am beyond my paygrade here. Please someone who can talk to olde Phartes... MAYBE this could be SPECTRUM/Charter??? They are a royal pain in the tush. sending mail to spam that is not & ignoring that I tell them it is real; changing font sizes when I am typing; & other crummy stuff.

title: Untimely connection of Firefox servers
content:
Firefox declare to be aware of privacy but as soon as I use Firefox to go on the internet, I immediately get connections from these 2 addresses : 34.107.243.93 34.107.221.82 in addition to the address of the site I connect to.

And sometimes, I receive so many connection attempts on ports that are not implied in the connection I have established with the initial site (conntrack) that I am obliged to disconnect the network. An example below : oct. 06 16:10:59 localhost kernel: net-fw DROP IN=enp5s0 OUT= MAC=f0:2f:74:22:64:20:70:fc:8f:50:5b:de:08:00 SRC=34.107.221.82 DST=10.98.0.24 LEN=52 TOS=0x00 PREC=0x00 TTL=121 ID=19614 PROTO=TCP SPT=80 DPT=59118 WINDOW=1050 RES=0x00 ACK FIN URGP=0 oct. 06 16:10:59 localhost kernel: net-fw DROP IN=enp5s0 OUT= MAC=f0:2f:74:22:64:20:70:fc:8f:50:5b:de:08:00 SRC=34.107.221.82 DST=10.98.0.24 LEN=52 TOS=0x00 PREC=0x00 TTL=121 ID=19615 PROTO=TCP SPT=80 DPT=59118 WINDOW=1050 RES=0x00 ACK FIN URGP=0 oct. 06 16:11:00 localhost kernel: net-fw DROP IN=enp5s0 OUT= MAC=f0:2f:74:22:64:20:70:fc:8f:50:5b:de:08:00 SRC=34.107.221.82 DST=10.98.0.24 LEN=52 TOS=0x00 PREC=0x00 TTL=122 ID=19616 PROTO=TCP SPT=80 DPT=59118 WINDOW=1050 RES=0x00 ACK FIN URGP=0 oct. 06 16:11:00 localhost kernel: net-fw DROP IN=enp5s0 OUT= MAC=f0:2f:74:22:64:20:70:fc:8f:50:5b:de:08:00 SRC=34.107.221.82 DST=10.98.0.24 LEN=52 TOS=0x00 PREC=0x00 TTL=122 ID=19617 PROTO=TCP SPT=80 DPT=59118 WINDOW=1050 RES=0x00 ACK FIN URGP=0 oct. 06 16:11:01 localhost kernel: net-fw DROP IN=enp5s0 OUT= MAC=f0:2f:74:22:64:20:70:fc:8f:50:5b:de:08:00 SRC=34.107.221.82 DST=10.98.0.24 LEN=52 TOS=0x00 PREC=0x00 TTL=124 ID=19618 PROTO=TCP SPT=80 DPT=59118 WINDOW=1050 RES=0x00 ACK FIN URGP=0 oct. 06 16:11:03 localhost kernel: net-fw DROP IN=enp5s0 OUT= MAC=f0:2f:74:22:64:20:70:fc:8f:50:5b:de:08:00 SRC=34.107.221.82 DST=10.98.0.24 LEN=52 TOS=0x00 PREC=0x00 TTL=122 ID=19619 PROTO=TCP SPT=80 DPT=59118 WINDOW=1050 RES=0x00 ACK FIN URGP=0 oct. 06 16:11:06 localhost kernel: net-fw DROP IN=enp5s0 OUT= MAC=f0:2f:74:22:64:20:70:fc:8f:50:5b:de:08:00 SRC=34.107.221.82 DST=10.98.0.24 LEN=52 TOS=0x00 PREC=0x00 TTL=121 ID=19620 PROTO=TCP SPT=80 DPT=59118 WINDOW=1050 RES=0x00 ACK FIN URGP=0

This does not happen with other browsers like Konqueror, Falcon, etc. I suffered an attack in this way in the past with heavy consequences. Is there a way to configure Firefox in order to suppress it ?

title: Mozilla is not showing an embedded video in normal size, while it shows correctly in Edge and Chrome
content:
My problem is the following. The website of my favorite football club regularly embeds videos within their pages. Clicking of the video within the club webpage shows the video without leaving the webpage. Recently opening the club site with mozilla stopped enabling me to see the embedded videos. An example of what I see on my screen now when using mozilla is in the first image uploaded below - instead of showing the embedded video, all I see is a small red rectangle with a "play" button in it. If I press the play button, the video starts, but shows within the extremely small rectangle and I cannot watch it.

This is not so when I use Edge or Chrome, as shown on the second image uploaded below, showing the exact same webpage (the address is https://levski.bg/video/%f0%9f%94%b5-%d0%bb%d0%b5%d0%b2%d1%81%d0%ba%d0%b8-31-%d0%b1%d0%b5%d1%80%d0%be%d0%b5-%d0%b3%d0%be%d0%bb%d0%be%d0%b2%d0%b5-%d0%b5%d0%bc%d0%be%d1%86%d0%b8%d0%b8-%d1%80%d0%b5%d0%bf%d0%be/ ). The embedded video is clearly seen in its full size within the page, and when I click the play button it starts showing the video normally within the webpage without leaving the site and sending me to youtube, for example.

My question is, what is wrong and what can I do to start seeing the embedded videos normally again?

Thank you, Georgy Ganev

title: Request for Debugging Help: Significant Performance Drop in Firefox with Specific CSS Feature
content:
Dear Mozilla Community,

I hope this message finds you well. I am a web developer reaching out for assistance with a puzzling performance issue that appears to be unique to the Firefox browser.

I have implemented a fairly standard modern layout technique on my website, [ https://chipotlmenu.com/ ], utilizing complex CSS Grid and subgrid definitions, along with will-change properties for minor animations.

While the site loads and runs smoothly on all Chromium-based browsers and Safari, I have observed a dramatic and consistent drop in frame rate, often leading to temporary freezing, specifically in Firefox (latest desktop version) when interacting with the main navigation area.

The issue seems to be tied to how Firefox is handling the repainting or compositing of the elements nested within the CSS Grid structure. Disabling the will-change properties does alleviate the issue, but this compromises the intended user experience.

I would be incredibly grateful if members of the community, particularly those with expertise in Firefox's rendering engine (Gecko) or CSS performance profiling, could visit the site and help diagnose the specific bottleneck.

To reproduce the issue:

Access the website, using the latest stable version of Firefox.

Navigate the main menu or hover over the interactive components on the homepage.

Check the Firefox Performance Profiler (via DevTools) to see if you can isolate the specific layout/rendering task consuming the most time.

Any insights into whether this is a known Gecko behavior, a bug, or an optimization I'm missing would be extremely helpful.

Thank you for your valuable time and expertise.

Best regards,

Shahzain shahzainsajid12@gmail.com
creator: shahzainsajid12

title: Firefox 143.0.3 is  a terrible, jacked-up mess!!!
content: I was updated to 143.0.4 a couple of days ago. Ever since, I've had all kinds of issues. Some sites won't load properly. Some links are not clickable. We're talking sites I use all the time and have never seen this happen before. I have not changed anything in my firewall or antivirus and have used them for years with Firefox. I refreshed and nothing. I actually uninstalled Firefox, cleaned out the registry entries, and installed 143.0.3 today. And yes, I did set it to not auto-update. Still misbehaving. I don't know if I missed a reg key that might be the culprit. I'm currently using Chrome Canary - although it's not my favorite, it is working normally on the same sites I've tried with Firefox. I even opened Edge for the first time in ages - it's working fine as well! I love Firefox, but I don't know what to do at this point! Please, can you help?
